seriesMenu.title: The C series contains the following 17 lessons

entries.title: Lesson C1     S, T, N and E
Lesson C2     Learning the SHIFT key

lesson_C1.1.title: Lesson C1.1: Tutorial
text: Lesson C1
Welcome to the Colemak Course
This course is intended for beginners as well as experienced typists.  The
Colemak keyboard is an alternative to the QWERTY (Sholes) keyboard layout.
You will find it easier to learn than the QWERTY and Dvorak keyboard layouts.
Like the Dvorak keyboard, this is because the Colemak keyboard layout has been
scientifically designed to minimise cumulative finger motion while typing
English.  The ten letters on the home row (A, R, S, T, D, H, N, E, I, and O)
make up about 70% of all keystrokes.  These ten letters alone can form over
3000 words.  Needless to say, having these keys in the home row facilitates
both speed and accuracy.
Unlike the Dvorak keyboard layout, however, the Colemak keyboard layout has
also specifically been designed to be easy to learn for people who are already
familiar with using a QWERTY keyboard layout.  Despite this, it appears that
the Colemak keyboard is as fast as, if not faster than, the Dvorak keyboard.
For information about the Colemak keyboard layout, see <http://colemak.com/>.

lesson_C1.2.title: Lesson C1.2: Tutorial
text: General Instructions
The fingers of the left hand should be placed over the A-key, the R-key,
the S-key, and the T-key.  Similarly, the fingers of the right hand should be
placed over the N-key, the E-key, the I-key, and the O-key.  This is called the
HOME position.  Only these fingers should be used to press the keys that they
are above.
In addition to these keys, the SPACE bar should be pressed with the thumb of
the right hand.  At the end of every line, the RETURN key should be pressed
with the fourth finger of the right hand.

text: General Instructions
When you need to press the D-key or the H-key, the first finger of the left or
right hand, respectively, should be used.  No other finger should be used.

lesson_C14.1.title: Lesson C14.1: Tutorial
text: Learning the SHIFT key
To integrate the shift key rhythmically in your practice, a capital letter
should take three beats:
1. press the shift key opposite the hand to press the letter key
2. press the letter
3. release the shift key

text: Ada Anne Ana Ann Dad Dan Don Ed Eta Rita
Dan Nan Nat Ned Sid Sire Tad Ted Tod Rene

lesson_C14.3.title: Lesson C14.3: Drill

He ate ten stones

lesson_C14.4.title: Lesson C14.4: Drill
text: On his date Otis has a thin suit
There is no tint on his shoes

lesson_C14.5.title: Lesson C14.5: Drill
text: Enos eats a thin hash diet in a dish as he sits on an odd seat
Dad does not eat desert
He had seen Ted dent his auto

lesson_C15.1.title: Lesson C15.1: Tutorial
text: Learning punctuation
The period/full stop is below the forth finger on the right hand.  Note that
the end of a sentence should be followed by two spaces; in abbreviations, it is
followed by one space.
The comma is below the third finger on the right hand.
The fourth finger of the right hand and the left SHIFT key should be used to
type a question point/mark.

lesson_C15.2.title: Lesson C15.2: Drill

h.  r.  a.  i.  o.  n.  s.  d.  t.  e.  h.  o.  r.  i.  s.  a.

lesson_C15.3.title: Lesson C15.3: Drill
lesson_C15.3.text: Adana.  Andie.  Annie.  Aonia.  Ardie.  Denis.  Diana.  Dinah.

lesson_C15.4.title: Lesson C15.4: Drill
text: On the horse, Adana dined in haste on toast and dates.
Sated, as she had eaten she noted the sheen on the drones
and the shade in the sheds.  She hates to see an idiot
stand and shoot his tenth doe in the dense heath.

lesson_C15.5.title: Lesson C15.5: Drill
text: An onion heats, stunned, a stout nose.  As does she?  As do I?
Do I send hands to douse teeth?  Are their suedes hoisted ahead?

lesson_C15.6.title: Lesson C15.6: Drill
text: The shy ape put on a red hat and ran off with the lot.  Can pa
go aft and lie on our old cot?  For a top fee, her act is to hop
in, lie on the rug, pat her pet cat, fit a fur on her ear, get
her fan, and run off.

lesson_C16.1.title: Lesson C16.1: Tutorial
text: Frequent words
The following 135 words are so frequently used that they comprise 50% of all
words normally typed.  If you can type the next two exercises without errors,
half of all of your typed words will be correct!

text: We now concentrate on words amongst the top one thousand most frequently used
that are 4 letters or more and that can be types using only the HOME row.

lesson_C17.1.title: Lesson C17.1: Tutorial
text: Alphabetic sentences
In this lesson we practice alphabetic sentences.

lesson_C17.2.title: Lesson C17.2: Drill
lesson_C17.2.text: Sixty-five quizzical sheep kept their jaws dry in a farm bungalow.

lesson_C17.3.title: Lesson C17.3: Drill
lesson_C17.3.text: Balky Zulus find they can hoax weary men with quavery jumping.

lesson_C17.4.title: Lesson C17.4: Drill
lesson_C17.4.text: Jerome quickly began to be vexed by the powerful blizzards.

lesson_C17.5.title: Lesson C17.5: Drill
lesson_C17.5.text: Squawking gorillas could vex the brazen nymphs in a jiffy.

lesson_C17.6.title: Lesson C17.6: Drill
lesson_C17.6.text: Can Jerry's equipment file saws, ax, hoe, knives and grind adz?

lesson_C17.7.title: Lesson C17.7: Drill
lesson_C17.7.text: Ben works at squeezing very juicy plums with flexed thumbs.

lesson_C17.8.title: Lesson C17.8: Drill
lesson_C17.8.text: The black wizard quipping jovially flexed his muscles.

lesson_C17.9.title: Lesson C17.9: Drill
lesson_C17.9.text: Will you pack my jugs of liquid veneer in five dozen boxes?

lesson_C17.10.title: Lesson C17.10: Drill
lesson_C17.10.text: Could the wizard jinx quivering folks by magic yelps?

lesson_C17.11.title: Lesson C17.11: Drill
lesson_C17.11.text: Brazen gazelles quickly examined the forward jeep.

lesson_C17.12.title: Lesson C17.12: Drill
lesson_C17.12.text: The brown dog quickly jumped over the lazy fox.

lesson_C17.13.title: Lesson C17.13: Drill
lesson_C17.13.text: Will the kind judge squelch the five or six brazen nymphs?

lesson_C17.14.title: Lesson C17.14: Drill
lesson_C17.14.text: Mix zippy Kadota figs with quivering cranberry jelly.

lesson_C17.15.title: Lesson C17.15: Drill
lesson_C17.15.text: The wives quickly jerked extra big pizzas from the stand.

lesson_C17.16.title: Lesson C17.16: Drill
lesson_C17.16.text: Lisa quickly mixed the very big jar of new soap.

lesson_C17.17.title: Lesson C17.17: Drill
lesson_C17.17.text: The major will fix a quiet cozy nook for the vexed, bad Gypsy.

lesson_C17.18.title: Lesson C17.18: Drill
lesson_C17.18.text: Pairs of lazy knowing oxen came by quietly evading the jam.

lesson_C17.19.title: Lesson C17.19: Drill
lesson_C17.19.text: Juvenile zest for excitement whetted interest in parking by the quay.

lesson_C17.20.title: Lesson C17.20: Drill
lesson_C17.20.text: Put your big ax, shovel and quartz where Mike's fence joins ours.

lesson_C17.21.title: Lesson C17.21: Drill
lesson_C17.21.text: The brawny jaguar held fast till the quaking Zouave victim expired.
